questions.question: I have a son and a daughter. …………… of them are good at maths.
questions.description: We use both to talk about two people or things. All and every are used to talk about more than two people or things.

questions.question: You can’t get there without ……………
questions.description: Singular countable nouns take an article or another determiner with them.

questions.question: What did you do with ……………. I lent you?
questions.description: We use ‘the’ when we say which one we mean.

questions.question: Do you like …………..?
questions.description: No article is used with a plural noun when we are talking about things in general.

questions.question: The teacher asked me to do the homework ……………
questions.description: In American English, over and again are both possible here. In British English, only again is used.

questions.question: We have lived …………… this street for ten years.
questions.description: In American English, on is used here whereas in British English, in is used.

questions.question: I am proud to be ………… the national football team.
questions.description: In American English, on is used here in British English, in is used here.

questions.question: One should love …………… neighbors.
questions.description: In British English, one’s is required whereas in American English, ‘his’ is possible here.

questions.question: It is important that she ……………
questions.description: We have used a special structure called the subjunctive here. In British English, the subjunctive is unusual and the structure with should + infinitive is used instead.

questions.question: I have never really …………… to know him.
questions.description: In American English, the past participle of get is gotten. In British English, the past participle of get is got.

questions.question: The birds have …………….. south for the winter.
questions.description: Flown is the past participle form of fly. To fly is to move in the air.

questions.question: I ………….. down and closed my eyes.
questions.description: Lay is the past tense of lie. To lie is to ‘be down’.
